title: Incorporating predation diffusion
text: Let us assume prey abundance given power law: \(N_c(w)=N_0w^{-\lambda}\) predation kernel \[ \phi(w/w_p) = \exp\left(-\frac{\log(w/w_p/\beta)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right). \] juveniles \(\psi(w)=0\) hence integral expression Eq. 2 growth rate becomes \[ I_g:=\int N_c(w_p)\phi(w/w_p)\alpha\,(1-\psi(w)) w_p\,dw_p = \alpha\int w_p^{1-\lambda}\exp\left(-\frac{\log(w/w_p/\beta)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)dw_p. \] integral can evaluated easily changing integration variable \(x=\log(w_p/w_0)\)arbitrary reference weight \(w_0\) recognising resulting integral \[ I_g=\alpha\, w_0^{2-\lambda}\int e^{(2-\lambda)x}\exp\left(-\frac{(x-\log(w/w_0)+\log(\beta))^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)dx \] Gaussian integral. Using general result \[ \int e^{ax}\exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)dx = \sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{\sigma^2}}\exp\left(\mu+\frac{^2\sigma^2}{2}\right) \] \(= 2-\lambda\) \(\mu = \log(w)-\log(\beta)\) find \[ \begin{split} I_g&= \alpha\, w_0^{2-\lambda}\sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{\sigma^2}}\exp\left((2-\lambda)(\log(w/w_0)-\log(\beta))+\frac{(2-\lambda)^2\sigma^2}{2}\right)\\ &=\alpha w^{2-\lambda}\sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{\sigma^2}}\beta^{\lambda - 2}\exp\left(\frac{(2-\lambda)^2\sigma^2}{2}\right) \end{split} \] Assuming constant feeding level \(f(w)=f\), allometric metabolic loss rate \(K(w) = k_s w^n\) allometric search volume \(\gamma(w)=\gamma w^q\) exponent \(q = n + 2 - \lambda\) obtain \[ g(w) = \left((1-f)\gamma \alpha \sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{\sigma^2}}\beta^{\lambda - 2}\exp\left(\frac{(2-\lambda)^2\sigma^2}{2}\right)-k_s\right) w^n. \] assume metabolic loss fraction \(f_c/f\) incoming energy (refer \(f_c\) critical feeding level) simplifies \[ g(w) =\left( \left(1-\frac{f_c}{f}\right)(1-f)\gamma \alpha \sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{\sigma^2}}\beta^{\lambda - 2}\exp\left(\frac{(2-\lambda)^2\sigma^2}{2}\right)\right) w^n. \tag{3}\] can evaluate diffusion rate \(d(w)\) manner. extra factor \(w_p\) changes \(\) \(2-\lambda\) \(3-\lambda\) obtain \[ d(w) = \left((1-f(w))\gamma \alpha^2 \sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{\sigma^2}}\beta^{\lambda - 3}\exp\left(\frac{(3-\lambda)^2\sigma^2}{2}\right)\right) w^n. \] Comparing expression Eq. 3 \(g(w)\) find \[ d(w) = g(w)w\frac{1}{1-f_c/f}\frac{\alpha}{\beta}\exp\left(\frac{(2\lambda - 3)\sigma^2}{2}\right). \] get feel typical magnitude factor let’s consider concrete values \((1-f_c/f)=0.6\), \(\alpha = 0.8\), \(\beta = 100\), \(\sigma = 1\) \(\lambda = 2\). \(d(w) \approx 0.02 g(w)w\). However see value \(d(w)\) strongly influenced width feeding kernel. choose \(\sigma = 2\) \(d(w)\approx0.1g(w)w\). increase diffusion rate increasin \(\sigma\) may explains result (Datta et al. 2010) stability system increases increasing \(\sigma\).

title: Incorporating predation diffusion
text: Now ready investigate effect diffusion slope juvenile spectrum steady state. Without diffusion find juvenile spectrum solving steady-state equation \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial w}(g(w) N(w)) =-\mu(w) N(w). \] solution \[ N(w) = \frac{g(w_0)}{g(w)}N(w_0)\exp\left(-\int_{w_0}^w\frac{\mu(w')}{g(w')}dw'\right). \] allometic growth death rates \(g(w)=g_0w^n\) \(\mu(w)=\mu_0w^{n-1}\) gives \[ N(w)=\left(\frac{w}{w_0}\right)^{-n} N(w_0)\exp\left(-\frac{\mu_0}{g_0}\int_{w_0}^w\frac{1}{w'}dw'\right)=N(w_0)\left(\frac{w}{w_0}\right)^{-\mu_0/g_0-n} \] Thus juvenile steady state abundance density given power law exponent \(-\mu_0/g_0-n\). presence diffusion steady state equation becomes second-order ODE \[ \frac12 \frac{\partial^2}{\partial w^2}(d N) - \frac{\partial}{\partial w}(g N)-\mu N=0. \tag{4}\] seen previous section \(g(w)=g_0w^n\) diffusion rate also power law one extra factor \(w\): \(d(w)=d_0w^{n+1}\). makes equation Eq. 4 scale invariant hence expect solution power law, make Ansatz \(N(w)=N(w_0)(w/w_0)^\) exponent \(\) determined. Substituting Ansatz Eq. 4 gives \[ \frac12 d_0N_0(n+1+)(n+)w^{n+-1} -g_0N_0(n+)w^{n+-1}-\mu_0 N_0w^{n-1+} = 0 \] requires \[ \frac12 d_0(n+1+)(n+) -g_0(n+)-\mu_0= 0. \] quadratic equation \(n+\): \[ \frac12 d_0 (n+)^2+\left(\frac12 d_0 -g_0\right)(n+)-\mu_0=0. \] two solutions \[ (n+a_\pm) = \frac1{d_0}\left(g_0-d_0/2\pm\sqrt{(g_0-d_0/2)^2+2d_0\mu_0}\right) \] interested solution goes \(=-\mu_0/g_0-n\) \(d_0\0\). means interested solution - sign. check indeed solution \(a_{-}\) satisfies \(\lim_{a_-\0}= -\mu_0/g_0-n\) helpful expand square root term around \(d_0=0\): \[ \sqrt{(g_0-d_0/2)^2+2d_0\mu_0}=g_0+\frac{-g_0+2\mu_0}{2g_0}d_0+\frac{g_0^2-(-g_0+2\mu_0)^2}{8g_0^3}d_0^2+\dots \] find \[ \begin{split} &= -n+\frac1{d_0}\left(g_0-d_0/2-\sqrt{(g_0-d_0/2)^2+2d_0\mu_0}\right)\\ &\approx -n-\frac{\mu_0}{g_0} - \frac18\left(1-\left(-1+2\frac{\mu_0}{g_0}\right)^2\right) d_0+\dots\\ &=-n-\frac{\mu_0}{g_0} +\frac12\left(\frac{\mu_0}{g_0}\left(1-\frac{\mu_0}{g_0}\right)\right)\frac{d_0}{g_0}+\dots \end{split} \] see \(\mu_0=g_0\) first correction term juvenile slope vanishes. largest increase slope (.e., least negative slope) achieved \(\mu_0/g_0=1/2\). case slope without diffusion \(-1.25\) (assuming $n=0.75). correction term \(1/8 d_0/g_0\). already seen previous section \(d_0/g_0\) typically small, change slope also small. Using example value \(d_0/g_0=0.002\) \(n=0.75\) get slope correction \(0.00025\) \(-1.25\) \(-1.24975\). Using value \(d_0/g_0=0.1\) get larger slope correction \(0.0125\) \(-1.25\) \(-1.2375\). still seems irrelevant, remember looking power law exponent small changes exponent can large effect value power law. , example, fixed abundance eggs size 0.001g look resulting density fish 1000g, diffusion correction increases factor \((10^6)^{0.0125}\approx 1.19\), increase 19\%. \(\mu_0/g_0>1\) diffusion correction negative, .e., juvenile slope becomes negative due diffusion, meaning fewer large fish.

title: Incorporating predation diffusion
text: Mizer works logarithmically-spaced weight bins. good, makes complicated work numerical schemes solving equations. much easier work equally-spaced bins. obvious solution view logarithm weight independent variable instead weight. work \[ x = \log(w/w_0) \] \(w_0\) arbitrary reference weight. transforms logarithmically-spaced bins \(w\) equally-spaced bins \(x\). also work abundance density function \(x\). Let’s denote \(n(x)\). related abundance density \(N(w)\) \[ n(x)dx = N(w)dw \] \(dx = dw / w\) means \(N(w)=n(w)/w\). chain rule \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial w} = \frac{\partial x}{\partial w}\frac{\partial}{\partial x} = \frac{1}{w}\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \] can now transform PDE Eq. 1 \(N(w,t)\) PDE \(n(x,t)\): \[ \frac{\partial n}{\partial t} = \frac12 \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{1}{w}\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\frac{d n}{w}\right) - \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\frac{g n}{w}\right)-\mu n \tag{5}\] rewrite using \[ \frac{1}{w}\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\frac{d n}{w} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\frac{d n}{w^2}+\frac{d n}{w^2} \] Introducing rescaled growth diffusion rates \[ \tilde{g} = \frac{g}{w}-\frac12\frac{d}{w^2},~~~~\tilde{d}=\frac{d}{w^2} \] simplifies PDE Eq. 5 \[ \frac{\partial n}{\partial t} = \frac12 \frac{\partial^2}{\partial x^2}(\tilde{d}n) - \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\tilde{g}n\right)-\mu n \tag{6}\] Note diffusion rate just rescaled factor \(1/w^2\) expected transformation \(d^2/dw^2\) \(d^2/dx^2\), growth rate also received additional contribution diffusion. can also write PDE form derivatives act directly \(n\) expanding \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\tilde{g}n\right) = \tilde{g}'n + \tilde{g}n' \] \[ \frac12 \frac{\partial^2}{\partial x^2}(\tilde{d}n)=\frac12\tilde{d}''n+\tilde{d}'n'+\frac12\tilde{d}n'' \] denoted derivative respect \(x\) prime. Collecting terms gives \[ \frac{\partial n}{\partial t} = \frac12 \tilde{d}n'' - \left(\tilde{g}-\tilde{d'}\right)n'-\left(\mu +\tilde{g}'-\frac12\tilde{d}''\right)n \]
code: w <- w(params) x <- log(w / w[1]) h <- x[2] - x[1]

title: Incorporating predation diffusion
text: can now obtain steady-state abundance density solving second-order ODE \[ ''-bn'-cn=0 \] \[ = \frac12 \tilde{d},~~~~b=\tilde{g}-\tilde{d}',~~~~c=\mu +\tilde{g}'-\frac12\tilde{d}''. \] boundary conditions \[ n(x_0)=n_0,~~~~n(x_{max})=0. \] \(x_{max}\) size fish can never reach. solve second-order finite-difference scheme, using equally-spaced grid spacing \(h\): \(x_i = x_0 + ih\) \(=0,\dots,N+1\) \(x_{N+1}=x_{max}\). use notation \(n(x_i)=n_i\). finite-difference approximations derivatives \[ n'(x_i)=\frac{n_{+1}-n_{-1}}{2h},~~~~n''(x_i)=\frac{n_{+1}-2n_i+n_{-1}}{h^2}. \] gives us linear system \[ U_i n_{+1}+D_i n_i+L_i n_{-1}=0 \tag{7}\] \[ U_i=a_i-\frac{h}{2}b_i, \qquad L_i=a_i-\frac{h}{2}b_i \qquad \text{ }~~~D_i = -2a_i-h^2c_i \] \(=1,\dots,N\). can solved making Ansatz \[ n_{-1}=\alpha_in_i+\beta_i \tag{8}\] \(=1,\dots N\), \(\alpha_i\) \(\beta_i\) determined. Substituting Eq. 8 Eq. 7 gives \[ U_in_{+1}+(\alpha_iL_i+D_i)n_i+\beta_iL_i=0. \tag{9}\] Similarly using \(n_{}=\alpha_{+1}n_{+1}+\beta_{+1}\) Eq. 9 gives \[ \left[U_i + (\alpha_iL_i+D_i)\alpha_{+1}\right]n_{+1}+\left[(\alpha_iL_i+D_i)\beta_{+1}+\beta_iL_i\right]=0. \tag{10}\] can satisfy making expressions square brackets vanish, gives us \[ \alpha_{+1}=-\frac{U_i}{\alpha_iL_i+D_i},\qquad \beta_{+1}=-\frac{\beta_iL_i}{\alpha_iL_i+D_i}. \tag{11}\] Looking Eq. 8 \(=1\), .e., \(n_0 = \alpha_1n_1+\beta_1\) see can choose \(\alpha_1=0\) \(\beta_1=n_0\). can now use Eq. 11 determine \(\alpha\)s \(\beta\)s. Starting boundary condition \(n_{N+1}=0\) can use Eq. 8 determine remaining \(n_i\). scheme known stable \(U_i,L_i>0\), \(D_i<0\) \(U_i+L_i\leq -D_i\). requirement \(U_i>0\) gives us maximum step size \[ h\leq\frac{\tilde{d}}{\tilde{g}-\tilde{d}'}. \] implement function solve_steady_state_ode follows:
code: solve_steady_state_ode <- function(a, b, c, n0, h) {     # Number of interior points     N <- length(a) - 1          # Calculate finite difference scheme coefficients     U <- a - h/2 * b     # Upper diagonal     L <- a + h/2 * b     # Lower diagonal      D <- -2*a - h^2 * c  # Main diagonal          # Check stability conditions     if (any(U <= 0) || any(L <= 0) || any(D >= 0)) {         warning("Stability conditions not met. Try reducing step size h.")     }     if (any(U + L > -D)) {         warning("Stability condition U + L <= -D not met.")     }          # Solve using double sweep method     n <- solve_ode_double_sweep(U, L, D, n0, N)          return(n) }  # Helper function for double sweep method solve_ode_double_sweep <- function(U, L, D, n0, N) {     # Initialize arrays for alpha and beta coefficients     alpha <- numeric(N + 1)     beta <- numeric(N + 1)     n <- numeric(N + 1)          # Initial conditions     alpha[1] <- 0     beta[1] <- n0          # Forward sweep - calculate alpha and beta coefficients     for (i in 1:N) {         denom <- alpha[i] * L[i] + D[i]         alpha[i + 1] <- -U[i] / denom         beta[i + 1] <- -(beta[i] * L[i]) / denom     }          # Backward sweep - calculate n values     n[N + 1] <- 0  # Boundary condition at x_max          # Work backwards to get remaining n values     for (i in N:1) {         n[i] <- alpha[i + 1] * n[i + 1] + beta[i + 1]     }          return(n) }

code: species <- "Cod" sps <- species_params(params)[species, ] n <- sps$n m <- sps$m w_mat <- sps$w_mat U <- log(3) / log(w_mat / sps$w_mat25) w_repro_max <- sps$w_repro_max mu <- getMort(params)[species, ] g <- getEGrowth(params)[species, ] # At small size we have $g(w) = g_0 w^n$, hence $g_0 = g(w)/w^n$ g_0 <- g[1] / w[1]^n dgdw <-    g_0 * w^(n - 1) * (n -    (m + (m  - U) * (w / w_mat)^U) * (w / w_repro_max)^(m - n) /    (1 + (w / w_mat)^U)^2) d_0 <- 0.1 * g_0 d <- d_0 * w^(n + 1) dprime <- (n + 1) * d_0 * w^(n) dtilde <- d / w^2 dtildeprime <- (n - 1) * d_0 * w^(n - 2) dtildepp <- (n - 2) * (n - 1) * d_0 * w^(n - 3) gtilde <- g / w - 0.5 * dtilde gtildeprime <- dgdw - g / w - 0.5 * dtildeprime  a <- 0.5 * dtilde b <- gtilde - dtildeprime c <- mu + gtildeprime - 0.5 * dtildepp n0 <- initialN(params)[species, 1] * w[1] n <- solve_steady_state_ode(a, b, c, n0, h) #> Warning in solve_steady_state_ode(a, b, c, n0, h): Stability conditions not #> met. Try reducing step size h. #> Warning in solve_steady_state_ode(a, b, c, n0, h): Stability condition U + L <= #> -D not met. plot(x, n, type = "l")

title: Extending an Ecopath model to a mizer model
text: package provides framework setting calibrating multi-species size spectrum models using mizer package. offers tools assist translating empirical observations, species-specific biomass, consumption, production rates, steady-state models ecologically coherent. goal make process building, tuning, validating mizer models accessible, robust, transparent. methods designed support applications ranging academic research exploratory ecosystem analysis policy-relevant fisheries modelling.

title: Get diffusion rate — getDiffusion
text: diffusion rate \(d_i(w)\) species \(\) weight \(w\) contributions encounter fish prey resource. determined summing prey species resource spectrum integrating prey sizes \(w_p\), weighted predation kernel \(\phi(w,w_p)\): $$ d_i(w) = (1-f_i(w))(\alpha_i(1-\psi_i(w)))^2\gamma_i(w) \int \left( \theta_{ip} N_R(w_p) + \sum_{j} \theta_{ij} N_j(w_p) \right) \phi_i(w,w_p) w_p^2 \, dw_p. $$ \(N_j(w)\) abundance density species \(j\) \(N_R(w)\) abundance density resource. overall prefactor \(\gamma_i(w)\) determines predation power predator. interpreted search volume set setSearchVolume() function. predation kernel \(\phi(w,w_p)\) set setPredKernel() function. species interaction matrix \(\theta_{ij}\) set setInteraction() resource interaction vector \(\theta_{ip}\) taken interaction_resource column params@species_params. \(f(w)\) feeding level calculated getFeedingLevel(). \(\psi(w)\) proportion available energy invested reproduction instead growth, stored params@psi.

what: Get respiration rate as defined by Ecopath — getRespiration
title: Get respiration rate as defined by Ecopath — getRespiration
text: Unlike getMetabolicRespiration(), function follows Ecopath definition respiration rate assimilated food used production. expressed first master equation Ecopath: $$Q = P + R + U$$ \(Q\) consumption rate, \(P\) production rate, \(R\) respiration rate, \(U\) unassimilated part consumption rate, .e., \(U = (1 - \alpha) Q\), \(\alpha\) assimilation efficiency. Solving \(R\) get: $$R = \alpha Q - P$$

title: Match the observed catch and yield — matchCatch
text: Currently function implemented case single gear catching species. function sets new values following parameters: l50: size gear selectivity 50%. l25: size gear selectivity 25%. catchability: catchability gear. mu_mat: external mortality maturity. parameters selected species adjusted. function recalculates corresponding rate arrays params object. sets initial size spectrum steady state size spectrum. total biomass species remains unchanged. function estimates parameters minimizing objective function. objective function negative log likelihood observed catch size distribution given probabilities predicted model plus sum squares difference log observed yield log predicted yield, multiplied yield_lambda, well sum squares difference log observed production log predicted production, multiplied production_lambda. function deals missing data following way, species individually: observed yield available, function match observed catch size distribution observed production. observed production available, function match observed catch size distribution observed yield. observed catch size distribution available, function match observed yield observed production. neither observed yield observed production available, function raises error. catch predicted model calculated integrating catchability gear selectivity size distribution species. size distribution shaped model interplay growth mortality. gear selectivity catchability need adjusted together parameters shape size distribution. objective function coded C++ TMB package used compile objective function create functions automatically calculating gradients. passed nlminb function minimize objective function.

title: Match the observed catch and yield — matchCatch
code: params <- matchCatch(celtic_params, species = "Hake", catch = celtic_catch) plot_catch(params, species = "Hake", catch = celtic_catch)  # The function leaves the biomass of the species unchanged all.equal(getBiomass(params), getBiomass(celtic_params), tol = 1e-4) #> [1] TRUE # It also leaves the energy available to an individual for reproduction # and growth unchanged all.equal(getEReproAndGrowth(params), getEReproAndGrowth(celtic_params)) #> [1] TRUE # The initial size spectrum is set to the steady state size spectrum params_steady <- steadySingleSpecies(params) all.equal(initialN(params), initialN(params_steady)) #> [1] TRUE

title: Match the model's production rate to empirical observations/estimates — matchProduction
text: Ecopath explicitly account loss due gonad production. However energy invested gonad production lost due inefficiency reproductive process. Therefore mizer need include loss respiration rate. Thus $$R = K + G - R_dd * w_0$$ \(K\) metabolic rate, \(G\) gonadic production rate, \(R_dd\) rate offspring production, \(w_0\) weight offspring size enters model. Thus \(G - R_dd * w_0\) net loss due gonad production. matchProduction function calls matchProductionOnce() repeatedly production matches within tolerance specified tol parameter. function return warning maximum number iterations reached without converging.
